docs.snippet: ON shore, the Midsummer's Eve bonfires twinkle dimly in the sunshine as we sail out of Bergen. Jet-lagged, we seek out our cabin and go to bed long before dark. It is about 11 P.M., and by the time our ship makes port in Floro -- the first of seve...
docs.lead_paragraph: ON shore, the Midsummer's Eve bonfires twinkle dimly in the sunshine as we sail out of Bergen. Jet-lagged, we seek out our cabin and go to bed long before dark. It is about 11 P.M., and by the time our ship makes port in Floro -- the first of several dozen stops on this 2,500-mile voyage along the western coast of Norway -- we are sound asleep, missing one of the few chances that we are going to have to watch the sun set. My husband, Tom, and I have signed on for a round-trip cruise on Bergen Line's Nordnorge, one of 11 ships that sail, year round, from Bergen around the North Cape to Kirkenes, a town a few miles from the Russian border. The voyage encompasses the better part of 12 days and, for all practical purposes -- much of our route is above the Arctic Circle, and it is the latter part of June -- no nights.
docs.abstract: Travel article by Sarah Ferrell on 2,500-mile voyage along western coast of Norway on Bergen Line's cruise ship Nordnorge; map; photos (L)

headline.main: Scenic Days And Nights Off Norway

docs.snippet: Last fall, as the Broadway season was kicking into high gear, it looked to be dominated by musicals, and so it has been. But what then seemed to be a dearth of straight plays is turning into a relative plenitude.     Already open and surviving, to...
docs.lead_paragraph: Last fall, as the Broadway season was kicking into high gear, it looked to be dominated by musicals, and so it has been. But what then seemed to be a dearth of straight plays is turning into a relative plenitude. Already open and surviving, to varying degrees, are David Mamet's ''Old Neighborhood,'' an updated revival of ''The Diary of Anne Frank,'' a new production of Arthur Miller's ''View From the Bridge,'' Jack Klugman and Tony Randall in ''The Sunshine Boys'' and Gip Hoppe's ''Jackie.''
docs.abstract: On Stage and Off column; Liam Neeson to play Oscar Wilde in David Hare's play Judas Kiss; production to play in London for five weeks and then open on Broadway April 29, deadline for Tony eligibility; Richard Eyre directs; Neeson comments; photo; Woodie King of New Federal Theater discusses cooperative project with Max Ferra's Intar Hispanic-American Arts Theater and Tisa Chang's Pan Asian Rep; multicultural program, Three by Three, features plays by Nikos Kazantzakis, Manuel Puig and Edward Sakamoto; Power Plays by Alan Arkin and Elaine May to open at Promenade Theater, with May's daughter Jeannie Berlin and Arkin's son Anthony in cast (S)

headline.main: David Hare Play Arrives in April

docs.snippet: For those who regard theatergoing as blood sport, it promised to be the event of the season. A budget of $11 million; a world-famous composer new to the Broadway musical and openly contemptuous of its traditions; a protracted period of previews re...
docs.lead_paragraph: For those who regard theatergoing as blood sport, it promised to be the event of the season. A budget of $11 million; a world-famous composer new to the Broadway musical and openly contemptuous of its traditions; a protracted period of previews replete with tales of desperate last-minute revisions, a frenzied parade of advice-dispensing show doctors: ''The Capeman,'' Paul Simon's pop-operatic retelling of a street-gang murder in 1959, seemed to have all the elements that make theater-disaster cultists drool. But it would take a hard-core sadist to derive pleasure from the sad, benumbed spectacle that finally opened last night at the Marquis Theater, three weeks behind schedule. Although it may be unparalleled in its wholesale squandering of illustrious talents, including those of the Nobel Prize-winning poet Derek Walcott (Mr. Simon's co-librettist and book writer) and the brilliant choreographer Mark Morris (the director of record), ''The Capeman'' is no fun even as a target.
docs.abstract: Ben Brantley reviews Broadway musical The Capeman, with music, book and lyrics by Paul Simon; Derek Walcott is co-lyricist, Mark Morris director and choreographer; photos (M)

headline.main: The Lure of Gang Violence To a Latin Beat

docs.snippet: Twenty years ago, there were dozens of family dynasties in the antiques trade in Manhattan. Now there are 15. That's why it's worth noting the reopening on Wednesday of the Blumka Gallery of medieval and Renaissance art, at 209 East 72d Street, it...
docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, there were dozens of family dynasties in the antiques trade in Manhattan. Now there are 15. That's why it's worth noting the reopening on Wednesday of the Blumka Gallery of medieval and Renaissance art, at 209 East 72d Street, its fifth home in Manhattan. Anthony Blumka, great-grandson of the founder, has transformed a town house into a soaring gallery to display bronze and wooden sculptures, Gothic enamels and ivories, Renaissance jewelry, and medieval and Renaissance furniture.
docs.abstract: Antiques column on reopening of Blumka Gallery of medieval and Renaissance art; notes that new space on East 72d Street in Manhattan is fifth New York home for family business that began in Austria in 19th century; photo; Leopopld Blumka was forced to close Vienna gallery in 1939, but re-established business in Ne York (S)

docs.snippet: The Central Intelligence Agency today released the first volume of an internal investigation concluding that the agency knew nothing about California cocaine dealers who claimed connections with rebels in Nicaragua backed by the agency.    The ins...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Central Intelligence Agency today released the first volume of an internal investigation concluding that the agency knew nothing about California cocaine dealers who claimed connections with rebels in Nicaragua backed by the agency. The inspector general's report was an effort to answer accusations made in newspaper articles published in August 1996 that drug-dealing Nicaraguan rebels and their supporters were responsible for introducing crack cocaine to black neighborhoods in California in the 1980's.
docs.abstract: Central Intelligence Agency releases first volume of internal investigation concluding that agency knew nothing about California cocaine dealers who claimed connections with rebels in Nicaragua backed by agency; report is effort to answer accusations made by San Jose Mercury News in Aug 1996 that drug-dealing Nicaraguan rebels and their supporters were responsible for introducing crack cocaine to black neighborhoods in California in 1980's (M)

headline.main: C.I.A. Report Concludes Agency Knew Nothing of Drug Dealers' Ties to Rebels

docs.snippet: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews...
docs.lead_paragraph: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8. Now Playing ''AMISTAD,'' starring Djimon Hounsou, Anthony Hopkins and Matthew McConaughey. Directed by Steven Spielberg (R, 150 minutes). Irrefutably worthy in its attention to a long-overlooked chapter in American history, this story of a slave mutiny and subsequent trial is still a film whose zestiest character is John Quincy Adams (played by Mr. Hopkins). It has great earnestness, impeccable credentials and Mr. Spielberg's great storytelling power. What it lacks is an Oskar Schindler, a flawed, three-dimensional character through whom the atrocity of slavery can be understood. The best moments in this long, instructive tale are those that simply bring the slaves' pride, fear and outrage to life. Mr. McConaughey, the weak link in casting that includes Nigel Hawthorne as Martin Van Buren, should cease and desist from playing any more smart lawyers (Janet Maslin).

docs.snippet: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.    RON AFFIF, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Mr....
docs.lead_paragraph: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. RON AFFIF, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Mr. Affif is a burly, tough guitarist who moves easily between straight-ahead swinging and more experimental sounds. And though he likes velocity -- lots of notes, lots of places -- he can play chorus after chorus of riff or melody. His band, including Essiet Essiet on bass and Jeff Watts on drums, is extraordinary, the product of years of working together. There are three sets, at 8, 10 and 12, with no third set on Sunday. There is a $20 cover tonight and tomorrow; $15 cover on Sunday; $10 drink minimum on all nights (Peter Watrous).

docs.snippet: The dancers are vibrant, the production is good-humored, the set is witty and the music is by Johann Strauss 2d, the Waltz King. Only the choreography is inept in the ''Cinderella'' that the Ballet Nacional de Cuba brought to City Center on Tuesda...
docs.lead_paragraph: The dancers are vibrant, the production is good-humored, the set is witty and the music is by Johann Strauss 2d, the Waltz King. Only the choreography is inept in the ''Cinderella'' that the Ballet Nacional de Cuba brought to City Center on Tuesday night for its first New York engagement since 1979. The ballet does not live up to its clever front curtain. But this did not deter a warm reception at the start of a week's run, when Alicia Alonso, the company's founder and once one of American ballet's great ballerinas, came out for a bow.
docs.abstract: Anna Kisselgoff reviews performance by Ballet Nacional de Cuba, at City Center; photo (M)

headline.main: A Cuban Cinderella Awhirl To a Strauss Waltz Score
